deliberation: Checked for metaphors, idioms, and personification. The verse is largely formulaic narrative, but the clause 'the word that came to Jeremiah from YHWH' treats the abstract 'word' as an agent that 'comes', and 'word' itself stands for divine revelation. This is a standard prophetic formula but still figurative (personification + metonymy).

instances.english_text: The word that came to Jeremiah from GOD
vehicle: a concrete 'word' that can come from someone
ground: the revelation has a determinate content and origin and reaches Jeremiah as if sent
external, intentional communication from sender to recipient
conceptual mapping of messages as movable objects/agents
posture: prophetic narrator presents this as a standard way of describing revelation
instances.explanation: The abstract notion of divine revelation is expressed as a 'word' that actively 'comes' to Jeremiah, personifying the word and using 'word' metonymically for the whole revelatory event.

deliberation: Examined references to 'house' and other phrases. Two metonymic/idiomatic uses appear: 'house of the Rechabites' for the clan/family, and 'house of YHWH' for the temple as God's dwelling/place of worship.

instances.english_text: the house of the Rechabites
target: the clan or extended family group descended from Rechab
vehicle: household/building as emblem of a family
ground: a family typically inhabits a common dwelling and is identified with it
association of dwelling with its inhabitants
conceptual contiguity between place and people
posture: neutral narrative designation of the group
instances.explanation: The term 'house' does not refer to a specific structure but to the extended family or clan of the Rechabites, using the dwelling as a metonym for its inhabitants.

instances.english_text: the House of GOD
target: the Jerusalem temple as the cultic center where YHWH is worshiped
ground: the temple is perceived as YHWH's dwelling among His people
a dwelling signifies the presence and ownership of its lord
association between owner and house represents presence and authority
posture: theological metonymy embedded in temple ideology
instances.explanation: Calling the temple 'the House of GOD' uses the idea of a house to stand for the temple as YHWH’s dwelling and center of worship.

deliberation: The verse lists individuals and the group 'all the house of the Rechabites'. As in v.2, 'house' functions metonymically for the clan, not a literal house name. No other figurative language appears.

instances.english_text: all the household of the Rechabites
vehicle: a 'house' with all that it contains
ground: a household encompasses all members associated with a family dwelling
house symbolizes the entirety of a family group
use of container to represent its human contents
instances.explanation: 'House' denotes the extended family of the Rechabites, using the building/household as a metonym for the people composing it.

deliberation: Looked at 'House of YHWH' and the title 'man of God'. The first continues the metonymic temple language; the second is an idiomatic title for a prophetic/holy man, using 'of God' metonymically to define his role.

instances.english_text: the House of GOD
target: the temple in Jerusalem as worship site
ground: the temple functions as the locale of YHWH’s presence and honor
a house indicates residence and authority of its owner
place signifies its divine inhabitant
instances.explanation: As in v.2, 'House of GOD' uses domestic imagery for the temple as YHWH’s dwelling and cultic center.

instances.english_text: the man of God
target: a prophetic or specially devoted servant of YHWH (Hanan/that line)
ground: the person is uniquely associated with God’s service and authority
association with God defines his role and status
owner (God) stands for the sphere and authority in which the man operates
instances.explanation: 'Man of God' is an idiomatic title for a prophet or holy man; 'of God' metonymically expresses the person’s belonging to and representing God.

deliberation: Narrative description of placing wine before the Rechabites and inviting them to drink. No metaphor, personification, or idiom beyond literal action verbs.

The vow not to drink wine 'forever' is a legal-religious formulation. 'Ad-olam' 'forever' can sometimes be hyperbolic, but here it functions as a genuine perpetual prohibition across generations, not as obvious rhetorical overstatement. I do not treat it as figurative in this context.

Commands about not building houses, sowing, or planting vineyards and dwelling in tents are literal lifestyle prescriptions. Phrases like 'many days on the land where you sojourn' and 'on the face of the land' are standard Hebrew collocations; here they function straightforwardly without a distinct rhetorical figure.

Searched for idioms and conceptual metaphors. The key phrase is 'we have obeyed the voice of Jonadab' (literally 'we have listened in the voice'), which is an idiomatic/metonymic way to say 'obey his command'.

instances.english_text: And we have obeyed (lit. listened to) the voice of Jonadab son of Rechab our ancestor
ground: to obey is to heed and respond appropriately to what one hears
listening entails receptive, compliant attitude toward a speaker
sound/voice stands metonymically for command or authority
instances.explanation: The phrase uses 'listen to the voice' idiomatically for obeying a command, with 'voice' metonymically representing Jonadab’s directive.

deliberation: Continues literal description of Rechabite practice (not building houses, not owning vineyards/fields/seed). No marked figurative or idiomatic expressions beyond straightforward prohibition.
Statement that they dwell in tents and obey Jonadab. The imagery of tents is literal for a nomadic lifestyle, not used metaphorically here. No other figurative language detected.

Checked for idioms and metonymy. The phrase 'when Nebuchadnezzar ... went up against the land' uses 'the land' for the whole country/kingdom (people and territory), a common metonymy. The military motion verb 'go up' is conventional, but the key figurative element is 'land' as the object of invasion representing the polity.

instances.english_text: when King Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon invaded (lit. went up to) the country
target: the kingdom of Judah with its inhabitants and political reality
vehicle: the 'land' as geographical territory that one goes up against
ground: attacking a people is carried out by invading their land
territory represents the people and state rooted in it
place stands metonymically for its inhabitants and polity
posture: historical description using conventional war idiom
instances.explanation: Here 'the land' represents the whole kingdom and its people under attack, using territory metonymically for the political community.

deliberation: Same prophetic formula as v.1: 'the word of YHWH came to Jeremiah.' Again, the abstract 'word' is treated as an agent that comes, and 'word' stands for the full revelatory act.

instances.english_text: Then the word of GOD came to Jeremiah
vehicle: a 'word' that can come to someone
ground: revelation is experienced as a discrete communication originating from God
communication can be conceptualized as a moving object/agent
spoken word represents the broader revelatory encounter
instances.explanation: Personifies the divine 'word' as an entity that 'comes' to Jeremiah, using 'word' metonymically for the whole communication.

deliberation: Looked at divine titles and the exhortation. 'YHWH of Hosts' is a fixed title. The clause 'will you not take discipline to listen to my words' uses 'take discipline' as an idiomatic metaphor, treating instruction/reproof as something one can 'take' or 'accept' with the hand.

instances.english_text: Will you not take discipline to listen to My words?
target: Judah’s reception of God’s corrective teaching
vehicle: taking_hold_of 'discipline' as if it were an object
ground: accepting correction is like taking hold of something offered to you
voluntary reception and appropriation of instruction
conceptual metaphor: accepting teaching = taking/receiving an object
posture: divine rebuke framed as an appeal
instances.explanation: The verb 'take' with 'discipline' metaphorically depicts accepting God’s correction as grasping an offered object, an idiomatic exhortation to heed His words.

deliberation: Searched for conceptual metaphors and idioms. The distinctive figure is in 'I spoke to you, rising early and speaking' (hashkem ve-dabber), an anthropomorphic idiom for persistent, repeated effort, not literally God’s change of time-of-day.

instances.english_text: But I spoke to you persistently (lit. I spoke to you, rising early and speaking)
target: God’s persistent sending of messages to Judah
vehicle: a person who rises early and keeps speaking
ground: getting up early to address someone portrays zeal and persistence
continuous attempts over time are like repeated early visits
anthropomorphic metaphor of God as an early-rising messenger
instances.explanation: The phrase depicts God as one who repeatedly gets up early to speak, an idiomatic anthropomorphism conveying tireless persistence in sending His word.

deliberation: Multiple figurative expressions: (1) 'turn back, each from his evil way' uses the common metaphor of life-conduct as a path; (2) 'do not walk after other gods' treats religious allegiance as following a path/leader; (3) 'you did not incline your ear' is an idiom for paying attention/obeying. All are distinct though related conceptual metaphors.

instances.english_text: Turn back, every one of you, from his wicked way
vehicle: a 'way' or road one walks on and can turn back from
ground: patterns of behavior unfold over time like traveling along a road
changing conduct is like reversing direction on a path
conceptual metaphor: life/conduct = a path, repentance = turning back
posture: didactic use of everyday travel imagery
instances.explanation: Describes conduct as a 'way' and repentance as turning back from that path, using travel imagery for moral change.

instances.english_text: Do not follow after other gods to serve them
vehicle: walking after a leader along a path
ground: devotion and obedience resemble following someone’s lead
serving a deity is like walking in its train as a follower
conceptual metaphor: allegiance = walking after; worship = following
posture: warning cast in terms of misdirected following
instances.explanation: Portrays idolatry as 'walking after' other gods, using following on a path as a metaphor for religious allegiance and service.

instances.english_text: But you did not incline your ear
target: Judah’s attentiveness and willingness to heed God
vehicle: tilting one’s ear toward a speaker
ground: serious attention resembles leaning in to hear better
physical orientation of the ear images inward attentiveness
conceptual metaphor: paying heed = inclining the ear
posture: embodied-language idiom to stress refusal to listen
instances.explanation: The phrase uses bodily imagery—leaning the ear—as an idiom for giving earnest attention and obeying, here denied of Judah.

deliberation: Compared the obedience of Jonadab’s sons with Judah. The phrase 'this people has not listened to Me' uses 'listen' idiomatically for 'obey', an established auditory metaphor for responsiveness.

instances.english_text: but this people has not listened to Me
ground: obedience presupposes attentive hearing of instructions
ignoring someone’s words parallels disobeying them
conceptual metaphor: obedience = listening; disobedience = not listening
instances.explanation: Here 'listen' is idiomatic for 'obey'; saying they did not listen figuratively expresses their refusal to comply with God’s commands.

deliberation: Found two notable figurative elements: (1) 'I am bringing all the evil' where 'evil' stands for disaster/judgment; (2) the paired clauses 'I spoke... they would not listen; I called... they did not respond' extend the hearing/speaking metaphor to depict Judah’s refusal as ignoring a caller.

instances.english_text: all the disaster (lit. evil) with which I have threatened them
target: the concrete calamities coming upon Judah (war, exile, etc.)
ground: calamities are evaluated as morally bad and harmful
the result (harm, suffering) is labeled with the moral term ‘evil’
use of moral category to denote concrete disaster (metonymy of effect/quality)
posture: prophetic re-description of events as morally charged evil
instances.explanation: The term 'evil' functions as a metonym for the concrete calamities decreed, describing historical disaster with moral terminology.

instances.hebrew_text: יַעַן דִּבַּרְתִּי אֲלֵיהֶם וְלֹא שָׁמֵעוּ וָאֶקְרָא לָהֶם וְלֹא עָנוּ
instances.english_text: for I spoke to them, but they would not listen; I called to them, but they would not respond
target: Israel’s persistent refusal of God’s prophetic appeals
vehicle: a speaker/caller ignored by those addressed
ground: rejecting God’s message is like ignoring someone who speaks or calls to you
response to a summons parallels obedience to commands
conceptual metaphor: obedience = answering a call; refusal = remaining silent
posture: emphasizes God’s patience and Israel’s culpable silence
instances.explanation: Uses the imagery of one speaking and calling without answer to depict Israel’s refusal to heed God, extending the obedience-as-listening metaphor into a dialogue scenario.

deliberation: Examined commands and obedience language. The key figurative expression is 'you have kept all his commandments'—using the verb 'keep/guard' for careful observance, conceptualizing instructions as something one guards.

instances.english_text: and have kept all his commandments
vehicle: guarding or keeping something entrusted to you
ground: obedient observance resembles guarding a trust carefully
commands are conceptualized as valuables to be kept intact
conceptual metaphor: obeying instructions = keeping/guarding them
posture: covenantal-like obedience language applied to a family rule
instances.explanation: Uses 'keep' in its figurative sense for conscientious observance, likening commands to entrusted objects that must be guarded.

deliberation: Identified two idiomatic/metaphorical expressions: (1) 'there shall not be cut off a man' for the continuation/extinction of a lineage; (2) 'standing before Me' as an idiom for ongoing service or availability in God’s presence.

instances.english_text: There shall never cease to be someone (lit. a man shall not be cut off) from Jonadab son of Rechab
target: the ongoing survival of Jonadab’s lineage
ground: ending a lineage is like cutting something off so it no longer continues
destruction/removal images extinction of posterity
conceptual metaphor: termination of a family line = cutting off
posture: covenant-style idiom applied to a clan
instances.explanation: The idiom 'a man shall not be cut off' figuratively expresses that Jonadab’s line will not be extinguished, using cutting imagery for ending a lineage.

instances.english_text: standing before Me always (all the days)
target: perpetual availability for service in God’s presence by Jonadab’s descendants
vehicle: a servant or courtier physically standing before a king
attentive presence in front of a superior
ground: serving a superior involves standing attentively in his presence
unbroken availability is like continually standing ready before someone
conceptual metaphor: faithful service to God = standing in His presence
posture: courtly imagery adapted to divine-human relationship
instances.explanation: The phrase uses royal court imagery—standing before a king—as an idiom and metaphor for ongoing service and favored access in God’s presence.
